Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                <description>Using Camel with JTA Transaction Manager</description>
          
          
            
                <description>Enclose Camel routes in distributed transactions using Java Transaction API (JTA) and Narayana transaction manager</description>
          
      
    
    
  

If you like/accept the above proposal, please regenerate the docs.

replies.bodyText: JTA is not a spec of the distributed transaction. If we are talking about the distributed transaction, it means that the transaction can be propagated between the different processes, even the different hosts. That could be found in the JTS / OTS (CORBA) spec, etc.
replies.author: zhfeng

replies.bodyText:
I am a JTA noob. My info is from [1] where the lead
paragraph says

Java Transaction API (JTA) specifies standard Java interfaces between a transaction manager and the parties involved in a distributed transaction system

[1] https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/jta.html
replies.author: ppalaga

replies.bodyText:
OK, I see. For a typical JTA transaction used to update the two databases, just like
from("direct:update_two_databases")
    .transacted()
    .to("sql:update tbl?datasource=db1")
    .to("sql:update_tbl?datasource=db2")
The two database are "distributed" and both of them has a local transaction internally. The db talks to the transaction manager with the XA protocol and it is driven by the 2PC protocol to get to the consistent state whenever the transaction manager has a decision to commit or rollback a transaction. This transaction should be associated with a thread in the whole lifecycle of the processing.
Let's take a look at the following scenario, route 1 and route 2 are in the different process or host
route1
from("direct:update_two_databases_in_different_service")
    .transacted()
    .to("sql:update_tbl?datasource=db1")
    .to("http://localhost:8080/update_db2")
route2
from("netty-http:localhost:8080/update_db2")
    .transacted()
    .to("sql:update_tbl?datasource=db2")
So the transaction must be propagated between the http invoking, and we call it "the distributed transaction". But the JTA spec does not define the protocol of the transaction propagation. Then with the Narayana JTA implementation, I think it can not provide this capability.
replies.author: zhfeng

replies.bodyText:
@zhfeng I do not insist on the exact wording of my proposal. If you prefer removing "distributed" I am not against that. My intention was to make it a bit more informative. Most of our extension descriptions stick to a common style that can be characterized as follows:

Answers the question "What can I do with this?"
Starts with a verb in imperative - "Enclose" rather than "Enclosing", "You can enclose", etc.
Name the spec. implementation - Narayana in this case
Acronym comes in parentheses after the full name "Java Transaction API (JTA)"
replies.author: ppalaga

replies.bodyText: Thanks for the explanation and I prefer to remove the "distributed" and just "Enclose Camel routes in the transactions using Java Transaction API (JTA) and Narayana transaction manager".
replies.author: zhfeng

timeline.bodyText: I guess we do not want end users to override these methods or even call them directly? Hence we should perhaps make them package visible and final? Maybe the subclasses of TransactionalJtaTransactionPolicy could be made final too?
timeline.author: ppalaga

timeline.bodyText: Do not see any coverage for the individual various TransactionPolicies. Would it be hard to add a test route per policy?

timeline.message: Fix typo and remove the empty application.properties file

Add the tests for all the transation policies
Remove the NestedJtaTransactionPolicy as Narayana does not support nested transaction
Fix the MandatoryJtaTransationPolicy and NeverJtaTransactionPolicy
remove camel-quarkus-bom-deployment in the jta deployment
make sure it works in the native mode
